content.description:
2 bolts of easy climbing brings you to a steep overhang with good holds. Generally trend right and mind your footing on the dirty slab as you cross back to the left to the anchors. Short but rad!

The intimidating looking roof. Belay from below, climber starts by traversing in from the left on the ledge.
4 bolts, 2 fat metolius rap hangers, 1 with a quick link.

Start up the messy crack in the right facing corner at the base to a ledge ~3 m off the deck. reach out and clip your 2nd bolt, then enjoy! Crux comes in the vicinity of the 5th bolt, stellar climbing below, and above! Bring a few long draws to straighten your rope line. Look for the short, messy crack in a right facing corner that leads to a small ledge.
Start on the detached flake. 11 bolts, fixed anchor with chains

The first bolt protects a tricky slab move, which guards an easy ramp that leads you to a steep crux protected by the 5th bolt. Be aware, this crux is likely fairly height dependent! Easy terrain for a couple of bolts leads to enjoyable 5.10 climbing on somewhat delicate feeling rock to the chains.

Sus the route length, it's right around 30 meters, if not just a touch longer. With a 60 meter rope you may get down with stretch and simple shenanigens, just make sure to tie your knots!

3 metres right of Chain Lightening, the stepped roof trad line.
11 bolts, fixed anchor with chains

A stunning gear line which trends up and under a roof to a left-facing feature. Bomber gear and solid rock highlight this Kelowna classic.


SR to 2"

Climb a left leaning corner/ramp to start. The crux arrives at the same time you wonder where the route went (5 both protects the traverse crux), once you pass that, there is an open book roof with two run out bolts above the chimney.

Up the left trending ramp
10 bolts, fixed anchor with chains

Starts up a white streak from a block behind a large detached flake. Clip the first bolt from the ground. Several pistol squat style moves with minimal hand support lead you through the crux from bolts 2-4, with a heady run out from bolts 3-4. Gain a ledge with a tree to your left and then fire up the arete, look for the anchors to your left and mind the loose cube just above that beckons you to grab it.

Long draw or reach back and unclip the first bolt after the ledge- the kind bolters gave you this for your safety, but had to put it well left of the bolt line to find good rock. It's easy to grab this draw when you rap out.

Far left line of blots, 2m right of the moonlight crack
8 bolts, fat Metolius rap hangers

Climb up to the roof, clip overhead and over the lip, then continue up under the roof and step over to the right to clip your 4th bolt. Gather yourself and prepare for the slab crux! 1 more bolt and then link up with the route to the left at bolt 6, enjoying one more 5.10 roof after the ledge. 

3 lines cross the stepped roof, this is the middle one, also the right of the two lines that have bolts before crossing the roof.
11 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

A rad, varied climb including a slab crux from bolts 1-2, and cruxes at bolt roofs (5.11c for the first roof, 5.10 for the second roof). 

It is slightly run out to bolt 4 which is difficult to reach just over the 1st roof. I would suggest sacrificing your friend to hang the draws- once the draw is there the clip is easy. You can also clip a manky pin with an alpine draw below the first roof in the seam on the right, probably would avoid falling on it though.

Look for the stepped roof, this is the left most line that crosses (left to right) the roof at its high step.
8 bolts, 2 bolt anchor, plus an optional alpine draw for the pin.

Thin and delicate slab climbing; well protected and enjoyable!

The line immediately to the right of the detached flake that marks the far left of Main Wall.
6 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with rap rings

Climb fun slab (aka good movement, well protected, good holds, and most importantly, easy) to a simple boulder problem. The real boulder comes after a no hands ledge to gain the roof and turn the lip! Good holds to the chains after!

Consider extending several draws to straighten out the rope line a bit. 

30 m line, tie your knots!

Look for the bolt left of the tree in the roof, and trace the line down from there. 
11 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with chains.

Climb easy terrain (5.7) to a bucket undercling in a horizontal crack under the stepped roof, reach up and clip your high first bolt. Enjoyable climbing takes you to your last bolt which protects the crux. 

Look for the stepped roof, this line crosses the roof at the lower step. 
4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with chains.

The crux comes in the vicinity of the 2nd bold on technical face with small holds. Easier climbing leads you to the 1st anchor, but don't stop here! Continue up and right, and keep a cool head as you clip your next bolt on good holds. Continue easy (5.7) climbing to the top anchors.

30 m line, tie your knots!

Starts left of the big detached flake, passes right of the tree in the roof. You can also look for the open book feature of Detour, the line to the left. 
11 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with chains.

Techy, balancey slab from bolts 1-3, climbing eases after. Great rock!

First route clear left of the stepped roof.
6 bolts, 2 fat metolius rap hangers, 1 with a quick link.

This line traverses up and left along a weakness in the rock. Sustained technical face on thin but positive holds from bolts 1-4 (sloping mossy at bolt 4) leads you to easier, fun climbing up top. 

Long draw bolts 4 and 5. 

Look for the left leaning roof, this is the left leaning line just to the left.
7 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

Main wall is neatly broken in hand by the distinct zinger trad line. Solid rock and a mix o technical sport climbs. 
 South exposure
